name: Kinalas
description: A Bicol dish consisting of noodles (pancit) garnished by scraped meat from pork or beef's head and other parts, enhanced with a thick deep-brown sauce coming from the brains of a cow or pig.
ingredients: 2 tablespoons cornstarch, dissolved in 1/4 cup water
instructions: In a large pot, boil the pork or beef bones and meat with water. Skim off any scum that forms on the surface.
Add the onion, garlic, star anise, fish sauce, and soy sauce. Simmer for 1-2 hours or until the meat is tender.
Remove the meat from the broth, let it cool, then shred it into pieces.
Strain the broth to remove the bones and spices. Return the broth to the pot and bring it to a boil.
Add the dissolved cornstarch to the boiling broth to thicken it. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Cook the egg noodles according to package instructions. Drain and set aside.
To serve, place some noodles in a bowl, add the shredded meat, and pour the thickened broth over them.
Garnish with boiled egg, chopped spring onions, crispy garlic bits, and a squeeze of calamansi or lemon.

name: Bicol Express
description: A spicy Filipino stew made with two signature ingredients of Bicol cuisine: fiery-hot chilies and creamy coconut milk.
ingredients: 1 kg pork belly, cut into strips
6-8 pieces long green chili peppers (siling haba), sliced
2-4 pieces bird's eye chili (siling labuyo), chopped (optional, for extra spiciness)
instructions: In a large pan, sauté garlic, onion, and ginger until fragrant.
Add the pork belly strips and cook until they turn slightly brown.
Pour in the coconut milk and bring to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer for about 20-30 minutes or until the pork is tender.
Add the shrimp paste and mix well. Continue to simmer until the sauce thickens and the oil starts to separate from the coconut milk.
Add the long green chili peppers and bird's eye chili (if using). Cook for another 5-10 minutes or until the chilies are tender.
Pour in the coconut cream and simmer for an additional 5 minutes. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Laing
description: A Filipino dish of shredded or whole taro leaves with meat or seafood cooked in thick coconut milk spiced with labuyo chili, lemongrass, garlic, shallots, ginger, and shrimp paste.
ingredients: 6-8 pieces long green chili peppers (siling haba), sliced
2-4 pieces bird's eye chili (siling labuyo), chopped (optional, for extra spiciness)
instructions: In a large pot, combine coconut milk, garlic, onion, ginger, and shrimp paste. Bring to a boil.
Add the pork belly or shrimp (if using) and cook until tender.
Lower the heat and add the dried taro leaves. Press them down to soak in the coconut milk mixture. Do not stir to avoid releasing the itchy substance from the taro leaves.
Add the long green chili peppers and bird's eye chili (if using). Simmer for about 15-20 minutes or until the taro leaves are tender and the sauce has thickened.
Pour in the coconut cream and cook for another 5 minutes. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Pancit Bato
description: A local noodle dish made with Pancit Bato noodles, named after the town of Bato in Camarines Sur. It is typically sautéed with meat, vegetables, and soy sauce.
instructions: Boil Pancit Bato noodles until tender. Drain and set aside.
In a large pan, heat the cooking oil over medium heat. Sauté garlic and onion until fragrant.
Add the sliced pork or chicken and cook until browned.
Add the carrots and cabbage, and cook for a few minutes until vegetables are tender.
Add soy sauce, oyster sauce, and chicken broth. Stir well to combine.
Add the cooked Pancit Bato noodles and mix well until all ingredients are evenly distributed.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Garnish with chopped spring onions before serving.

name: Pinangat
description: A traditional Bicolano dish made with gabi (taro) leaves, filled with meat or fish, and cooked in coconut milk.
ingredients: 6-8 pieces long green chili peppers (siling haba), sliced
instructions: Prepare the filling: In a pan, heat some oil and saute the onion, garlic, and ginger until fragrant.
Add the ground pork or fish and shrimp paste. Cook until the meat is browned and cooked through.
Season with salt and pepper to taste. Set aside to cool slightly.
Prepare the gabi leaves: If the leaves are large, cut them into squares or rectangles. Blanch the leaves in boiling water for a few minutes to soften them. Drain and set aside.
Assemble the pinangat: Place a spoonful of the filling in the center of each gabi leaf. Fold the sides of the leaf to enclose the filling. Secure the sides with toothpicks or string (optional).

In a pot, arrange the pinangat packets in a single layer. Pour in the coconut milk and bring to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer for 15-20 minutes or until the gabi leaves are tender and cooked through.
Stir in the coconut cream and simmer for an additional 2-3 minutes. Season with salt and pepper to taste (optional).
Serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Puto Buko
description: A steamed rice cake from Bicol made with grated young coconut meat and glutinous rice flour. It's known for its chewy texture and slightly sweet flavor.
ingredients: Banana leaves, cut into squares (for wrapping)
instructions: In a large bowl, combine glutinous rice flour, young coconut meat, sugar, baking powder, and salt. Mix well.
Gradually add water while mixing until you get a thick and sticky batter.
Prepare banana leaves by lining them with small molds or cups. Pour the batter into the molds.
Steam for 20-25 minutes or until cooked through. A toothpick inserted into the center should come out clean.
Let cool slightly before serving.

name: Kandingga
description: A Bicolano delicacy made with pork blood, pork intestines, and spices. It's a rich and flavorful dish that's often served during special occasions.
ingredients: 500 grams pork intestines, cleaned and cut into pieces
instructions: In a pot, cook pork blood until it solidifies. Break it into small pieces and set aside.
In the same pot, saute onions, garlic, and ginger until fragrant.
Add pork intestines and cook until browned.
Stir in chili powder, salt, and pepper.
Pour in coconut milk and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat and simmer for 30-45 minutes or until the intestines are tender and the sauce has thickened.
Add cooked pork blood and stir to combine.
Serve hot with rice.

name: Sinantolan
description: A Bicolano soup made with pork, malunggay leaves, and spices. It's a nutritious and flavorful dish that's known for its health benefits.
instructions: In a pot, heat oil and saute onion and garlic until fragrant.
Add pork and cook until browned on all sides.
Pour in water and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat and simmer for 30-45 minutes or until the pork is tender.
Add malunggay leaves, salt, and pepper. Cook for a few more minutes until the malunggay leaves are wilted.
Serve hot with rice.

name: Ginataang Langka
description: A Bicolano dessert made with jackfruit, coconut milk, and sugar. It's a rich and sweet dish that's perfect for ending a meal.
instructions: In a pot, combine jackfruit, coconut milk, sugar, salt, and vanilla extract. Bring to a boil.
Reduce heat and simmer for 15-20 minutes or until the jackfruit is tender and the sauce has thickened.
Serve warm or cold.

name: Bicolano Adobo sa Gata
description: A unique take on the classic Filipino adobo dish. This version uses coconut milk instead of vinegar, creating a richer and creamier flavor profile.
ingredients: 500 grams chicken or pork, cut into pieces
instructions: In a pot, heat oil and saute onion and garlic until fragrant.
Add chicken or pork and cook until browned on all sides.
Pour in soy sauce, coconut milk, water (just enough to cover the meat), bay leaf, and peppercorns. Bring to a boil.
Reduce heat and simmer for 30-45 minutes or until the meat is tender and the sauce has thickened.
Season with salt to taste.
Serve hot with rice.

name: Baduya
description: A Bicolano dish also known as Maruya or Baduya for non-Bicolanos. It's a fritter made with thinly sliced saba bananas dipped in batter and deep-fried until golden brown and crispy.
ingredients: 5-6 ripe but firm saba bananas, peeled and sliced lengthwise into 1/4-inch thick pieces
instructions: In a large bowl, mix together flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt.
In a separate bowl, whisk together egg and milk (or water).
Gradually add the wet ingredients to the dry ingredients, mixing until just combined. Do not overmix.
Heat oil in a deep pot or fryer to 350°F (175°C).
Dip each banana slice into the batter, coating it evenly.
Carefully drop the coated banana slice into the hot oil and fry for 2-3 minutes or until golden brown and crispy.
Drain on paper towels to remove excess oil.
Serve hot with your favorite dipping sauce, like chocolate syrup, condensed milk, or vinegar with sugar.

name: Marcasotes
description: A Bicolano steamed cake traditionally made with just eggs, sugar, and flower petals (often gumamela or rose) for fragrance. Modern variations may include additional ingredients like vanilla extract or cheese.
ingredients: 1/4 cup rose petals (or gumamela petals), finely chopped (optional)
instructions: Preheat a steamer to medium heat.
In a large bowl, whisk together egg yolks and sugar until light and fluffy. You can use a hand mixer for this step.
If using, gently fold in the chopped rose petals or gumamela petals and vanilla extract (optional).
In a separate bowl, using clean beaters, whip egg whites until stiff peaks form. Be careful not to overbeat.
Gently fold the egg whites into the egg yolk mixture using a spatula. Do not overmix, as you want to maintain air in the batter for a fluffy cake.
Lightly grease small cupcake molds or paper muffin cups. You can also use small bowls or ramekins.
Fill the molds about ¾ full with the batter.
Steam the marcasotes for 15-20 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean. Be careful not to oversteam, as they can become tough.
Let the marcasotes cool slightly before serving. You can enjoy them warm or at room temperature.

name: Picadillo
description: A Bicolano fish dish made with stuffed tilapia (or other fish) with a flavorful filling of tomatoes, onions, garlic, ginger, and chilies. It's then cooked in coconut milk for a rich and slightly spicy dish.
ingredients: 1 whole tilapia (or other white fish), cleaned and scaled
1-2 chilies (depending on your spice preference), chopped
instructions: Prepare the stuffing: In a bowl, combine chopped tomatoes, onion, garlic, ginger, chilies, salt, and pepper. Mix well.
Stuff the fish: Carefully make a pocket in the belly of the fish. Stuff it with the prepared mixture. You can use toothpicks to secure the opening if needed.
Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Sear the fish on both sides until golden brown.
Pour in the coconut milk and bring to a simmer. Reduce heat and cover the pan. Simmer for 15-20 minutes or until the fish is cooked through and the sauce has thickened slightly.
Carefully transfer the fish to a serving plate. Spoon the coconut milk sauce over the fish.
Serve hot with rice and enjoy!

name: Biniribid
description: A Bicolano sweet snack or dessert made with rice flour and coconut milk, twisted into a rope-like shape, and deep-fried. It's known for its chewy texture, golden brown color, and a hint of sweetness. Biniribid can be enjoyed plain or dusted with sugar or glazed with caramelized brown sugar.
ingredients: 1/4 cup water (or more depending on consistency)
White sugar or brown sugar glaze (optional)
instructions: In a large bowl, combine glutinous rice flour, coconut milk, and white sugar. Mix well until you get a sticky dough. Gradually add water, a tablespoon at a time, until you achieve a manageable dough that's not too sticky.
Pinch off a small amount of dough and roll it into a long, thin rope about 1/4 inch thick. Twist the rope to create a spiral shape.
Heat oil in a deep pot or fryer to 350°F (175°C).
Carefully drop the twisted dough into the hot oil and fry for 2-3 minutes or until golden brown. Fry in batches to avoid overcrowding the pot.
Drain on paper towels to remove excess oil.
Enjoy plain or dust with white sugar while still warm. For a richer flavor, you can coat the biniribid with a brown sugar glaze (recipe below).

**Optional Brown Sugar Glaze:** In a small saucepan, combine 1/4 cup brown sugar and 1 tablespoon water. Heat over medium heat, stirring constantly, until the sugar dissolves and thickens slightly. Dip the fried biniribid in the glaze or drizzle it over the top.

name: Kusido
description: A Bicolano soup-based dish featuring fish and vegetables cooked in a slightly sour and flavorful broth. It's a staple dish in Bicol cuisine, known for its comforting and satisfying taste.
ingredients: 500 grams fish (suitable options include malasugi, maya-maya, hito, lapu-lapu, or your preferred type)
1 cup vegetables (common choices include sweet potato tops, kangkong (water spinach), okra, or a combination)
1-2 stalks sili haba (long green chili pepper), according to your spice preference
instructions: In a pot, bring water to a boil.
Add the fish and cook for a few minutes until partially cooked. Set aside.
In the same pot, saute onion and garlic until fragrant.
Add tomatoes and simmer for a few minutes until softened and releasing their juices.
Pour in the kalamansi juice and season with salt and pepper. Adjust the amount of kalamansi juice according to your desired level of sourness.
Add the vegetables and chili pepper. Simmer for 5-7 minutes or until the vegetables are tender-crisp.
Return the partially cooked fish to the pot and simmer for another 5-7 minutes or until the fish is fully cooked through.
Serve hot with rice and enjoy!
